item.description: “ I think that the serious psychological health of Jewish women is more important to Jewish law than encouraging stricter observance of Noahide law. “ https://t.co/4nA1OUqraC

item.description:
@jaymichaelson I suspect there may be a lot of Republican Jews who may be unpleasantly surprised by the rolling back of the Constitution to the 19th century, as much as they will applaud the return of child labor and the return of disproportional representation.

@jaymichaelson It’s not obvious that Maryland’s restriction of office holders to Christians wouldn’t pass constitutional muster given the current court’s stated principles.
item.source:markdown:
@jaymichaelson I suspect there may be a lot of Republican Jews who may be unpleasantly surprised by the rolling back of the Constitution to the 19th century, as much as they will applaud the return of child labor and the return of disproportional representation.
@jaymichaelson It’s not obvious that Maryland’s restriction of office holders to Christians wouldn’t pass constitutional muster given the current court’s stated principles.

item.description:
@AlexandraErin @tompeyer There used to be such people. They fought government suppression of speech at the Supreme Court and, in the 60s and 70s, decisively won. I expect we’ll see such people again soon at the Supreme Court, decisively losing in the 20s and 30s.

@AlexandraErin @tompeyer Ms. Paul is making their work harder.
item.source:markdown:
@AlexandraErin @tompeyer There used to be such people. They fought government suppression of speech at the Supreme Court and, in the 60s and 70s, decisively won. I expect we’ll see such people again soon at the Supreme Court, decisively losing in the 20s and 30s.
@AlexandraErin @tompeyer Ms. Paul is making their work harder.

item.description: @matthewjmiller7 @DBashIdeas Let me know if you want a review copy for the New Books Network.
item.source:markdown: @matthewjmiller7 @DBashIdeas Let me know if you want a review copy for the New Books Network.

item.description:
Your reminder that the NYTimes pays people to produce right wing disinformation, which generally works by highlighting a minor situation to obscure a major situation. https://t.co/hfjKycGNm2

Note that this works only because the NYTimes downplays right wing bad behavior. If Republican efforts in Virginia to sue book publishers and reverse decades of First Amendment law had been properly reported by the “paper of record,” the columnist couldn’t have ignored it.

And yes, there is a book that @BenYehudaPress hopes to publish in the next year or two which may be illegal to sell in certain states by then, given the Republican Supreme Court’s pledged goal of returning the Constitution to its 18th or 19th century reading.

I’m willing to gamble the minuscule advance I pay my authors that the #RogueSCOTUS will be right-sized before it rules on these matters and obligates Amazon to restrict sales of the book in Red States.

But if I were paying real money — you better believe there’d be a chilling effect.

But Ms. Paul’s job is not going explicitly not to tell you that Lolita and Origin of the Species could plausibly be banned in American states before the decade is over.
item.source:markdown:
Your reminder that the NYTimes pays people to produce right wing disinformation, which generally works by highlighting a minor situation to obscure a major situation. https://t.co/hfjKycGNm2
Note that this works only because the NYTimes downplays right wing bad behavior. If Republican efforts in Virginia to sue book publishers and reverse decades of First Amendment law had been properly reported by the “paper of record,” the columnist couldn’t have ignored it.
And yes, there is a book that @BenYehudaPress hopes to publish in the next year or two which may be illegal to sell in certain states by then, given the Republican Supreme Court’s pledged goal of returning the Constitution to its 18th or 19th century reading.
I’m willing to gamble the minuscule advance I pay my authors that the #RogueSCOTUS will be right-sized before it rules on these matters and obligates Amazon to restrict sales of the book in Red States.
But if I were paying real money — you better believe there’d be a chilling effect.
But Ms. Paul’s job is not going explicitly not to tell you that Lolita and Origin of the Species could plausibly be banned in American states before the decade is over.
